executive_summary: The Occupational Therapists industry comprises health practitioners who treat individuals with physical, mental, or developmental conditions. Therapists work to improve their client's ability to complete activities of daily living. Occupational therapy (OT) includes helping children with disabilities to participate fully in school and social situations, helping individuals recovering from injury to regain skills and providing support for individuals experiencing physical and cognitive challenges. The industry has benefited from growing demand for OT services and increased financial accessibility for patients due to disposable income growth and beneficial healthcare policies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: An Industry That Heals Others Heals Quickly After COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry endured pressure from COVID-19 as social distancing measures and safety protocols limited in-person appointments. Vaccine availability enabled a quick industry recovery and revenue bounded back in 2021. Pent-up demand, per capita disposable income growth, and total health expenditures supported revenue expansion through 2023.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Changes in Insurance Coverage and Increases in Income Empower Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid will increase, enhancing the financial accessibility of OT services. However, part of this growth could be due to healthcare inflation rather than increased coverage. While the decrease in individuals with private health insurance takes a slight dip, per capita disposable income and total health expenditures growth will support growth in services and allow revenue to grow faster than in previous years and be positive year to year.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Growing Skilled Industry Steps Up to Meet Varied Demands
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A boost in industry establishments and enterprises is expected to meet increased demand with some growth via consolidation.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demographic Changes Impact the Level of OT Services Needed
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Changing demographics are transforming demand for occupational therapy. The number of individuals aged 65 and older is projected to grow, and the median age is also expected to climb. This aging population will create a greater demand for OT services.

industry_definition: This industry includes independent health practitioners who help individuals with physical, mental or developmental conditions with daily living and working through everyday activities (occupations). More specifically, occupational therapy includes: helping children with disabilities to participate fully in school and social situations; helping individuals recovering from injury to regain skills; and providing support for individuals experiencing physical and cognitive changes.
key_trends: Demand for habilitative OT services has grown, mainly due to an aging population and the increasing prevalence of autism spectrum disorder (ASDs).
OT is a popular treatment strategy used during the rehabilitative process following an injury or surgery.

A greater need for OT services has coincided with increased accessibility to services due to several provisions of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) and an increase in the number of states with legislation that mandates coverage for autism.
Economic growth and several policy changes during the period, more people have been able to pay for OT services.

The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) expanded Medicaid eligibility, included rehabilitation and habilitation as required benefit categories, prohibited pre-existing condition exclusions and enabled more individuals and families with smaller incomes to access healthcare services, including OT services.
As of 2019, all 50 states and the District of Columbia have laws requiring insurance coverage for treating autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
Telehealth infiltrated the OT toolset, giving larger companies room to expand in an otherwise historically fragmented market.
Using technology (augmented reality, virtual reality, data analytics software) with mobile devices increases the quality and quantity of services.
As larger firms and therapists in large organizations access these innovations, the severity and scope of competition will boom.
Larger firms can hire occupational therapy assistants and save on wages, allowing the company to price more competitively or use savings for quality enhancements.
Physical therapists, speech-language pathologists and rehabilitation counselors can provide some services that therapists provide.
Larger firms have advantages in hiring occupational therapy assistants, allowing for competitive pricing and quality enhancements.
Telehealth coverage expanded after COVID-19 when many therapists transitioned from in-person treatment to remote delivery.
Since state governments and private insurers cover telehealth, remote delivery will widen markets and provide efficient, convenient service, supporting continued growth.

Integrating research results with clinical expertise and patient preferences is expected to achieve the best treatment outcomes and boost the popularity of OT as a treatment method, meeting demand of those hesitant to seek or refer services.
While many services are provided in hospitals, therapists work in various settings (schools, nursing facilities, outpatient clinics, homes), allowing services to be conveniently offered.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The need for occupational therapists (OTs) in hospitals is primarily driven by patients who experience physical or mental conditions that impede their ability to perform daily activities. OTs help such patients develop, maintain, or recover necessary skills, often on an inpatient basis.

In the educational sector, occupational therapists mainly support students with disabilities, although they may also assist other students experiencing problems. OTs help teachers design classrooms and devise strategies to manage diverse learning needs and behaviors.

Patients in skilled nursing facilities often need occupational therapy for rehabilitation or habilitation. Positive outcomes like shorter stays and higher functional improvements, as reported by the American Occupational Therapy Association, are driving demand within this market.

products_and_services.product_description: Direct client interventions constitute the largest share of industry revenue. Therapeutic intervention can be defined as an effort individuals or groups make to improve someone's well-being.

Indirect interventions constitute strategies or modifications for patients that they can use outside of direct counseling, such as developing therapeutic routines, modifying the physical environment or counseling a patient's various caregivers so they are better equipped to promote the treatment process.

The need for consultation services in various settings, like community centers, schools, and mental healthcare facilities, is becoming more prominent, particularly when addressing required changes to an individual's living environment.
Other miscellaneous services provided by occupational therapists.

Therapists, AOTA and other stakeholders have been working to develop occupational therapy into an evidence-based practice (EBP). As a result, more occupational therapists have been engaging in clinical research to further legitimize and improve treatment strategies.

tier_1_suppliers: Generic Pharmaceutical Manufacturing in the US
Brand Name Pharmaceutical Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Primary Care Doctors in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: An Aging Population Shapes the Types of Services Needed
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The trend of an aging population is increasing demand for geriatric occupational therapy. More seniors wish to maintain independence and age in place and these occupational therapists provide them with techniques to do so successfully.

business_locations.location_description: Southeast region of the US with a notable concentration of occupational therapy establishments.
Mid-Atlantic region with occupational therapy services.
West region of the US with occupational therapy services available.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FEDERAL AND STATE LICENSING, FIELDWORK AND CERTIFICATION
regulations_points.regulation_description: States and territories require occupational therapists to be licensed to practice, where requirements for licensure may require graduating from an accredited occupational therapy program, completing fieldwork requirements and passing the National Board for Certification in Occupational Therapy Certification Examination. Occupational therapists need to be certified for Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements.

The federal Anti-Kickback Law makes it a felony to intentionally offer, pay, solicit, or receive any remuneration in exchange for referring, recommending, arranging, purchasing, leasing, or ordering items or services covered by Medicare or Medicaid.

Occupational therapists are bound by multiple laws and regulations to ensure the privacy and security of medical records. They must safeguard the confidentiality of the information shared by their patients.

basis_points.basis_description: Service and relationship building with patient referral sources, including insurance companies and hospitals.
External competition forces innovation and adoption of new technology.

The key to gaining a competitive edge lies in offering exceptional and distinct services that differentiate them from others in the healthcare space, notably from similar healthcare providers like physical therapists.
Ensuring a well-staffed office of therapists and assistants can be difficult due to competition for skilled workers in densely populated markets with many healthcare providers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Personalized service, where services are tailored to individual needs, in person and one-to-one, requiring direct interaction, necessitates fragmented, dispersed provision.
Furthering the low concentration level is the presence of numerous nonprofit and community-based organizations offering occupational therapy services.
Different state requirements for occupational therapy certification prevent operational economies of scale.
Since services are locally provided, companies cannot exploit cost economies of more extensive, shared facilities and equipment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Key Monetary Considerations for Occupational Therapists
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Occupational therapists have to invest in specialized equipment and supplies like assistive devices and therapy materials to ensure effective service delivery. They need to spend on continuing education, including course fees, textbooks, and conferences, to stay updated with the latest therapy techniques and research. Necessary expenditures also include the costs related to obtaining and maintaining vital licenses and certifications. Running their own practice or clinic incurs overhead costs like rent, insurance, utilities, and administrative staff salaries.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Ensuring a well-staffed office of therapists and assistants can be difficult
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Ensuring a well-staffed office of therapists and assistants can be difficult due to competition for skilled workers in densely populated markets with many healthcare providers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: LONG LIVES AND LONG COVID IMPACT VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: As the elderly population increases, the demand for services offered in the occupational therapy industry grows. However, this surge adds unpredictability, as this population's fluctuating conditions and health needs can cause volatility. Occupational therapy is not considered as essential as other healthcare treatments so demand can fluctuate depending on economic conditions. However, the number of individuals suffering from long COVID may contribute to volatility as the impact ebbs and flows among the various age groups.

volatility_points.volatility_title: GOVERNMENT FUNDING FOR MEDICARE MAKES FOR VOLATILE REIMBURSEMENT
volatility_points.volatility_description: Any changes, especially cap increases for occupational therapy, can prompt a sudden rise in demand for occupational therapy services. Yet, these funding levels can vary yearly, creating instability in revenue and service demand for occupational therapists.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: DIRECT CLIENT INTERVENTION IS NECESSARY FOR HEALING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Direct client interventions constitute the largest share of industry revenue. Therapeutic intervention can be defined as an effort individuals or groups make to improve someone's well-being. For occupational therapists, this constitutes time directly counseling patients after an initial evaluation. Occupational therapy treatments and plans are tailored specifically to patients; therefore, interventions differ significantly from patient to patient.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: AN AGING POPULATION SHAPES THE TYPES OF SERVICES NEEDED
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The trend of an aging population is increasing demand for geriatric occupational therapy. More seniors wish to maintain independence and age in place and these occupational therapists provide them with techniques to do so successfully.

The need for consultation services in various settings, like community centers, schools, and mental healthcare facilities, is becoming more prominent, particularly when addressing required changes to an individual's living environment.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Indirect Interventions and Administrative Activities Fill Out the Day
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Indirect interventions constitute strategies or modifications for patients that they can use outside of direct counseling, such as developing therapeutic routines, modifying the physical environment or counseling a patient's various caregivers so they are better equipped to promote the treatment process. Occupational therapists must organize and maintain patient records and information collected through interviews, observations and tests.

Therapists, AOTA and other stakeholders have been working to develop occupational therapy into an evidence-based practice (EBP). As a result, more occupational therapists have been engaging in clinical research to further legitimize and improve treatment strategies.

FAQs.question: Has increased access to health insurance offered opportunities for your company?
FAQs.answer: As private insurance enrollment has risen, so has demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: How does your company target key potential markets?
FAQs.answer: Occupational therapists operate out of facilities that target specific markets like schools and nursing homes.

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need?
FAQs.answer: Occupational therapists are often based in highly populated areas.

FAQs.question: How does an increase in certain age groups affect your company's performance?
FAQs.answer: Occupational therapists often target seniors and children as specialty markets.

FAQs.question: Is your company keeping up-to-date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Occupational therapists often use equipment that is frequently upgraded.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored offering telehealth services to improve patient accessibility and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Some aspects of occupational therapy can be performed remotely or at home.

FAQs.question: Have any new mandates, as a result of healthcare reform, expanded your client base?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare reform has made it easier for individuals to access private and public health insurance.

FAQs.question: How does your company keep up with varying regulations across states?
FAQs.answer: Individual states have their own licensing requirements, so companies with operations in multiple states need to be aware of state regulations.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: To see the most patients possible, occupational therapists must stay efficient.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company have to replace its equipment?
FAQs.answer: Occupational therapy equipment is updated frequently.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to maintain a strong reputation? How have you developed your reputation? Do you have a large base of loyal customers?
FAQs.answer: Many patients and residents are referred to providers as a result of their reputation for quality of patient services and efforts to establish and build a relationship with them.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Occupational therapists tend to cluster in highly populated urban and suburban areas. Additionally, proximity to hospitals and other healthcare providers can help increase the number of referrals.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay up-to-date with new technology? Do you regularly update your reporting systems?
FAQs.answer: New technologies are increasingly being developed to better treat patients. Companies that are able to adopt these quickly can maintain a competitive edge. Reporting systems can also help track all costs and utilization of services.

FAQs.question: How much does your clinic rely on government funding? What percentage of your patients qualify for Medicare or Medicaid?
FAQs.answer: Medicare and Medicaid can provide coverage for occupational therapy services. As a result, increasing government funding for Medicare and Medicaid bolsters patients' demand for occupational therapy.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor trends in the unemployment rate? When the unemployment rate rises, how does that affect demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: As the national unemployment rate rises, fewer individuals have employer-mandated health insurance.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales are to adults 65 and over?
What are other markets significant to your business?
Median age of population
FAQs.answer: Older individuals are more likely to develop chronic conditions that require occupational therapy. As a result, an aging population bolsters demand for treatments provided by this industry.
